</EFX_COMPANY_INFORMATION>
<P>
<EFX_OPERATING_AND_FINANCIAL_REVIEW>
<A NAME="FIS_OPERATING_AND_FINANCIAL_REVIEW"></A>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<A NAME="A52931E20VF_HTM_107">
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	Item&nbsp;5.
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Operating and Financial Review and Prospects
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	The following discussion of our financial condition and results of operations should be read in
	conjunction with the consolidated financial statements and the related notes thereto, included
	under Item&nbsp;18.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	Overview
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	We intend this discussion to provide information that will assist in understanding our March&nbsp;31,
	2009 consolidated financial statements, the changes in significant items in those consolidated
	financial statements from year to year, and the primary reasons for those changes and the factors
	and trends which are anticipated to have a material effect on our financial condition and results
	of operations in future periods. This discussion includes information about our critical accounting
	policies and how these policies affect our consolidated financial statements, and information about
	the consolidated financial results of each business segment to provide a better understanding of
	how each segment and its results affect our financial condition and results of operations as a
	whole.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Our pre-tax results for fiscal years 2009 and 2008 were affected by favorable asbestos adjustments
	of $17.4&nbsp;million and unfavorable asbestos adjustments of $240.1&nbsp;million, respectively; impairment
	charges of nil and $71.0&nbsp;million, respectively; AICF SG&#038;A expenses of $0.7&nbsp;million and $4.0
	million, respectively; and ASIC expenses of $14.0&nbsp;million and $5.5&nbsp;million, respectively.
	Information regarding our asbestos-related matters and ASIC matters can be found in this
	discussion, Item&nbsp;3, &#147;Key Information &#151; Risk Factors,&#148; Item&nbsp;4, &#147;Information on the Company &#151;
	Commitment to Provide Funding on a Long-Term Basis in Respect of Asbestos-Related Liabilities of
	Former Subsidiaries&#148; and Notes 11 and 13 to our consolidated financial statements in Item&nbsp;18.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	The Company and the Building Product Markets
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Based on net sales, we believe we are the largest manufacturer of fiber cement products and systems
	for internal and external building construction applications in the United States, Australia, New
	Zealand, and the Philippines. Our current primary geographic markets include the United States,
	Australia, New Zealand, the Philippines, Europe and Canada. Through significant research and
	development expenditure, we develop key product and production process technologies that we patent
	or hold as trade secrets. We believe that these technologies give us a competitive advantage.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Our fiber cement products are used in a number of markets, including new residential construction
	(single and multi-family housing), manufactured housing (mobile and pre-fabricated homes), repair
	and remodeling and a variety of commercial and industrial applications (stores, warehouses,
	offices, hotels, motels, schools, libraries, museums, dormitories, hospitals, detention facilities,
	religious buildings and gymnasiums). We manufacture numerous types of fiber cement products with a
	variety of patterned profiles and surface finishes for a range of applications, including external
	siding and soffit lining, internal linings, facades, fencing and floor and tile underlayments.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Our products are primarily sold in the residential housing markets. Residential construction levels
	fluctuate based on new home construction activity and the repair and renovation of existing homes.
	These levels of activity are affected by many factors, including home mortgage interest rates, the
	availability of financing to homeowners to purchase a new home or make improvements to their
	existing homes, inflation rates, unemployment levels, existing home sales, the average age and the
	size of housing inventory, consumer home repair and renovation spending, gross domestic product
	growth and consumer confidence levels. A number of these factors continued to be generally
	unfavorable during fiscal year 2009, resulting in weaker residential construction activity.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	Fiscal Year 2009 Key Results
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Total net sales decreased 18% to $1,202.6&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2009. We recorded an operating
	profit of $173.6&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2009 compared to an operating loss of $36.6&nbsp;million in
	fiscal year 2008, which was adversely affected by the unfavorable asbestos adjustment of $240.1
	million. We reported income from continuing operations of $136.3&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2009.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Our largest market is North America. Based on the NAHB&#146;s Builder Practices Reports, for the past
	three years, fiber cement has been one of the fastest growing segments (in terms of market growth)
	of the U.S. residential exteriors industry. During fiscal year 2009, USA and Europe Fiber Cement
	net sales contributed approximately 77% of total
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	50
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage53"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#A52931E20VF_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	net sales, and its operating income was the primary contributor to the total Company results. Net
	sales for our USA and Europe Fiber Cement business decreased due to a reduction in sales volume,
	slightly offset by a higher average net sales price.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Operating income for our USA and Europe Fiber Cement segment decreased from fiscal year 2008
	primarily due to reduced gross profit performance in the United States, which resulted from lower
	sales volume and higher average unit manufacturing costs.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	During fiscal year 2009, Asia Pacific net sales contributed approximately 23% of total net sales.
	Net sales decreased due to unfavorable currency exchange rates movements in the Asia Pacific
	business&#146; currencies compared to the U.S. dollar. In local currency, Asia Pacific net sales was
	flat.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	For further information regarding our business and operations, see Item&nbsp;4, &#147;Information on the
	Company.&#148;
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	Critical Accounting Policies
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	The accounting policies affecting our financial condition and results of operations are more fully
	described in Note 2 to our consolidated financial statements included in Item&nbsp;18. Certain of our
	accounting policies require the application of judgment by management in selecting appropriate
	assumptions for calculating financial estimates, which inherently contain some degree of
	uncertainty. Management bases its estimates on historical experience and other assumptions that are
	believed to be reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making
	judgments about the reported carrying value of assets and liabilities and the reported amounts of
	revenues and expenses that may not be readily apparent from other sources. Actual results may
	differ from these estimates under different assumptions and conditions. We consider the following
	policies to be the most critical in understanding the judgments that are involved in preparing our
	consolidated financial statements and the uncertainties that could impact our results of
	operations, financial condition and cash flows.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Accounting for Contingencies
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	We account for loss contingencies in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;5 under which we accrue amounts for
	losses arising from contingent obligations when the obligations are probable and the amounts are
	reasonably estimable. As facts concerning contingencies become known, we reassess our situation and
	make appropriate adjustments to the consolidated financial statements. For additional information
	regarding asbestos-related matters, ASIC proceedings, and Chile litigation, see Item&nbsp;3, &#147;Key
	Information &#151; Risk Factors,&#148; Item&nbsp;4, &#147;Information on the Company &#151; Commitment to Provide Funding on
	a Long-Term Basis in Respect of Asbestos-Related Liabilities of Former Subsidiaries,&#148; Item&nbsp;4,
	&#147;Information on the Company &#151; Legal Proceedings&#148; and Notes 11 and 13 to our consolidated financial
	statements in Item&nbsp;18.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Accounting for the Amended FFA
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Prior to March&nbsp;31, 2007, our consolidated financial statements included an asbestos provision
	relating to our anticipated future payments to the AICF based on the terms of the Original Final
	Funding Agreement as announced on December&nbsp;1, 2005 (which we refer to as the Original FFA).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	In February&nbsp;2007, the Amended FFA was approved to provide long-term funding to the AICF, a special
	purpose fund that provides compensation for Australian asbestos-related personal injury and death
	claims for which the Former James Hardie Companies are found liable.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	The amount of the asbestos liability reflects the terms of the Amended FFA, which has been
	calculated by reference to (but is not exclusively based upon) the most recent actuarial estimate
	of projected future cash flows prepared by KPMG Actuaries. Based on the their assumptions, the KPMG
	Actuaries arrived at a range of possible total cash flows and proposed a central estimate which is
	intended to reflect an expected outcome. The Company views the central estimate as the basis for
	recording the asbestos liability in the Company&#146;s financial statements, which under U.S. GAAP, it
	considers the best estimate under SFAS No.&nbsp;5. The asbestos liability includes these cash flows as
	undiscounted and uninflated on the basis that it is inappropriate to discount or inflate future
	cash flows when the timing and amounts of such cash flows is not fixed or readily determinable.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	51
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage54"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#A52931E20VF_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	The asbestos liability also includes an allowance for the future operating costs of the AICF.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	In estimating the potential financial exposure, KPMG Actuaries has made a number of assumptions.
	These include an estimate of the total number of claims by disease type which are reasonably
	estimated to be asserted through 2071, the typical average cost of a claim settlement (which is
	sensitive to, among other factors, the industry in which the plaintiff claims exposure, the alleged
	disease type and the jurisdiction in which the action is being brought), the legal costs incurred
	in the litigation of such claims, the proportion of claims for which liability is repudiated, the
	rate of receipt of claims, the settlement strategy in dealing with outstanding claims, the timing
	of settlements of future claims and the long-term rate of inflation of claim awards and legal
	costs.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Due to inherent uncertainties in the legal and medical environment, the number and timing of future
	claim notifications and settlements, the recoverability of claims against insurance contracts, and
	estimates of future trends in average claim awards, as well as the extent to which the above-named
	entities will contribute to the overall settlements, the actual amount of liability could differ
	materially from that which is currently projected and could result in significant debits or credits
	to the consolidated balance sheet and statement of operations.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	An updated actuarial assessment will be performed as of March&nbsp;31 each year. Any changes in the
	estimate will be reflected as a charge or credit to the consolidated statements of operations for
	the year then ended. Material adverse changes to the actuarial estimate would have an adverse
	effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	For additional information regarding our asbestos liability, see Item&nbsp;3, &#147;Key Information &#151; Risk
	Factors,&#148; Item&nbsp;4, &#147;Information on the Company &#151; Commitment to Provide Funding on a Long-Term Basis
	in Respect of Asbestos-Related Liabilities of Former Subsidiaries&#148; and Note 11 to our consolidated
	financial statements in Item&nbsp;18.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Sales Rebates and Discounts
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	We record estimated reductions to sales for customer rebates and discounts including volume,
	promotional, cash and other rebates and discounts. Rebates and discounts are recorded based on
	management&#146;s best estimate when products are sold. The estimates are based on historical experience
	for similar programs and products. Management reviews these rebates and discounts on an ongoing
	basis and the related accruals are adjusted, if necessary, as additional information becomes
	available.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Accounts Receivable
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	We evaluate the collectability of accounts receivable on an ongoing basis based on historical bad
	debts, customer credit-worthiness, current economic trends and changes in our customer payment
	activity. An allowance for doubtful accounts is provided for known and estimated bad debts.
	Although credit losses have historically been within our expectations, we cannot guarantee that we
	will continue to experience the same credit loss rates that we have in the past. Because our
	accounts receivable are concentrated in a relatively small number of customers, a significant
	change in the liquidity or financial position of any of these customers could impact their ability
	to make payments and result in the need for additional allowances which would decrease our net
	sales. For additional information regarding our customer concentration, see Item&nbsp;3, &#147;Key
	Information &#151; Risk Factors&#148; and Note 17 to our consolidated financial statements in Item&nbsp;18.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Inventory
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Inventories are recorded at the lower of cost or market. In order to determine market, management
	regularly reviews inventory quantities on hand and evaluates significant items to determine whether
	they are excess, slow-moving or obsolete. The estimated value of excess, slow-moving and obsolete
	inventory is recorded as a reduction to inventory and an expense in cost of sales in the period it
	is identified. This estimate requires management to make judgments about the future demand for
	inventory, and is therefore at risk to change from period to period. If our estimate for the future
	demand for inventory is greater than actual demand and we fail to reduce manufacturing output
	accordingly, we could be required to record additional inventory reserves, which would have a
	negative impact on our gross profit. For additional information regarding our inventories, see Item
	3, &#147;Key Information &#151; Risk Factors.&#148;
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	52
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage55"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#A52931E20VF_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Accrued Warranty Reserve
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	We offer various warranties on our products, including a 50-year limited warranty on certain of our
	fiber cement siding products in the United States. Because our fiber cement products have only been
	used in North America since the early 1990s, there is a risk that these products will not perform
	in accordance with our expectations over an extended period of time. A typical warranty program
	requires that we replace defective products within a specified time period from the date of sale.
	We record an estimate for future warranty-related costs based on an analysis by us, which includes
	the historical relationship of warranty costs to installed product. Based on this analysis and
	other factors, we adjust the amount of our warranty provisions as necessary. Although our warranty
	costs have historically been within calculated estimates, if our experience is significantly
	different from our estimates, it could result in the need for additional reserves. For additional
	information regarding warranties, see Item&nbsp;3, &#147;Key Information &#151; Risk Factors.&#148;
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Accounting for Income Tax
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	We account for income taxes according to FASB&#146;s Statement No.&nbsp;109, &#147;Accounting for Income Taxes,&#148;
	under which we compute our deferred tax assets and liabilities, which arise from differences in the
	timing of recognition of revenue and expense for tax and financial statement purposes. We must
	assess whether, and to what extent, we can recover our deferred tax assets. If full or partial
	recovery is unlikely, we must increase our income tax expense by recording a valuation allowance
	against the portion of deferred tax assets that we cannot recover. We believe that we will recover
	all of the deferred tax assets recorded (net of valuation allowance) on our consolidated balance
	sheet at March&nbsp;31, 2009. However, if facts later indicate that we will be unable to recover all or
	a portion of our net deferred tax assets, our income tax expense would increase in the period in
	which we determine that recovery is unlikely.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	We account for uncertain income tax positions according to FIN 48, &#147;Accounting for Uncertainty in
	Income Taxes an interpretation of FASB Statement No.109.&#148; Due to our size and the nature of our
	business, we are subject to ongoing reviews by taxing jurisdictions on various tax matters,
	including challenges to various positions we assert on our income tax returns. Positions taken by
	an entity in its income tax returns must satisfy a more-likely-than-not recognition threshold,
	assuming that the positions will be examined by taxing authorities with full knowledge of all
	relevant information, in order for the positions to be recognized in the consolidated financial
	statements. Each quarter we evaluate the income tax positions taken, or expected to be taken, to
	determine whether these positions meet the more-likely-than-not threshold prescribed by FIN 48. We
	are required to make subjective judgments and assumptions regarding our income tax exposures and
	must consider a variety of factors, including the current tax statutes and the current status of
	audits performed by tax authorities in each tax jurisdiction. To the extent an uncertain tax
	position is resolved for an amount that varies from the recorded estimated liability, our income
	tax expense in a given financial statement period could be materially affected.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	For additional information, see Item&nbsp;3, &#147;Key Information &#151; Risk Factors&#148; and Note 14 to our
	consolidated financial statements in Item&nbsp;18.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	53
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>

<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT; MARGIN-TOP: 16PT; WIDTH: 18%; BORDER-TOP: 1PX SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>

<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="96">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	On April&nbsp;1, 2008, the Company realigned its operating segments by combining the previously
	reported segments of USA Fiber Cement and Other into one operating segment, USA and Europe
	Fiber Cement. USA and Europe Fiber Cement includes all fiber cement manufactured in the United
	States and sold in the United States, Canada and Europe.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	The segment also includes fiber reinforced concrete pipes manufactured and sold in the
	United States (through May&nbsp;2008) and a roofing pilot plant in the United States (through
	April&nbsp;2006). Our Plant City, Florida Hardie Pipe Plant was closed and the business ceased
	operations in May&nbsp;2008. Our roofing pilot plant was closed and the business ceased
	operations in April&nbsp;2006.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	54
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>

<TD WIDTH="1%">

<TD WIDTH="96">
</TD>

<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	Fiscal year 2008 includes an asset impairment charge of $32.4&nbsp;million related to the
	suspension of production at our Blandon, Pennsylvania plant; an asset impairment charge of
	$25.4&nbsp;million related to the closure of our Plant City, Florida Hardie Pipe plant; and an
	asset impairment of $13.2&nbsp;million related to buildings and machinery utilized to produce
	materials for our products. See Note 7 to our consolidated financial statements in Item&nbsp;18.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(2)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	Fiscal years 2009 and 2008 include $0.7&nbsp;million and $4.0&nbsp;million, respectively, of AICF
	Selling, general and administrative expenses.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Year Ended March&nbsp;31, 2009 Compared to Year Ended March&nbsp;31, 2008
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<I>
	Total Net Sales
</I>
	. Total net sales decreased 18% from $1,468.8&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2008 to
	$1,202.6&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2009. Net sales from USA and Europe Fiber Cement decreased 21% from
	$1,170.5&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2008 to $929.3&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2009 due to decreased sales
	volume, slightly offset by a higher average net sales price. Net sales from Asia Pacific Fiber
	Cement decreased 8% from $298.3&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2008 to $273.3&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2009
	due to unfavorable currency exchange rate movements.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<I>
	USA and Europe Fiber Cement Net Sales
</I>
	. Net sales decreased 21% from $1,170.5&nbsp;million in fiscal year
	2008 to $929.3&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2009 due to decreased sales volume, slightly offset by a
	higher average net sales price. Sales volume decreased 22% from 1,951.2 mmsf in fiscal year 2008 to
	1,526.6 mmsf in fiscal year 2009, primarily due to weaker demand for our products in the U.S. as a
	result of continuing weakness in housing construction activity and deteriorating economic
	conditions. Although housing affordability has increased, we believe that demand is being
	restricted by limited availability of mortgage credit for prospective home buyers and lack of
	consumer confidence. The average net sales price increased 2% from $600 per msf in fiscal year 2008
	to $609 per msf in fiscal year 2009. As announced on May&nbsp;22, 2008, we have closed the USA Hardie
	Pipe business. An insignificant amount of sales related to this business were recorded in fiscal
	year 2009.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	The USA and Europe Fiber Cement business recorded its seventh consecutive quarter where sales
	declined compared to the corresponding quarter in the previous year, reflecting the on-going
	deterioration in U.S. housing starts. The NAHB reported U.S. housing starts of a
	seasonally-adjusted annual rate for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2009 of 523,000 units, down 50%
	from the 1.053&nbsp;million units for the corresponding quarter in fiscal year 2008.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	The decline in top-line performance was due to reduced exterior and interior product volumes, as
	product demand was lower in all regions. Lower SG&#038;A costs and a higher average selling price
	partially offset lower volumes and the higher unit cost of sales due to product mix and material
	costs. The business continues to focus on its three main strategic initiatives of primary demand
	growth, product mix shift and zero to landfill, and progress is being made on these initiatives
	despite softening market demand.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Our differentiated ColorPlus&#174; range of products continues to contribute to primary demand growth.
	Our initial focus on the ColorPlus range of products against vinyl siding manufacturers in the
	northern region of the United States has now been expanded to the western and southern regions of
	the United States with both areas posting moderate gains in ColorPlus penetration rate compared to
	fiscal year 2008.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	55
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage58"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#A52931E20VF_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Our growth strategy is complemented by accessories (particularly XLD
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: TEXT-TOP">
	TM
</SUP>
	trim,
	HLD
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: TEXT-TOP">
	TM
</SUP>
	trim and soffit) which provide a suite of exterior products for a &#147;full wrap&#148;
	solution to builders and remodelers. The strategy is further supported by positioning our interior
	backer products as a wet area wall solution, including G2
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 70%">
<SUP>
	1
</SUP>
</FONT>
	/
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 60%">
	2
</FONT>
	&#148; backer as the pre-eminent wet area
	solution and featuring Moldblock
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: TEXT-TOP">
	TM
</SUP>
	Technology on both
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 70%">
<SUP>
	1
</SUP>
</FONT>
	/
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 60%">
	4
</FONT>
	and
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 70%">
<SUP>
	1
</SUP>
</FONT>
	/
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 60%">
	2
</FONT>
	&#148; products. HardiZone
	exterior products are currently being launched in the U.S. These products are engineered for
	specific climate conditions utilizing our seventh generation product technology.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<I>
	Asia Pacific Fiber Cement Net Sales
</I>
	. Net sales decreased 8% from $298.3&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2008
	to $273.3&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2009 due to a 6% decrease in the average net sales price and a
	2%&nbsp;decrease in sales volume. Unfavorable currency exchange rates of the Asia Pacific business&#146;
	currencies compared to the U.S. dollar accounted for an 8% decrease in net sales in U.S. dollars.&nbsp;
	In Australian dollars, net sales were flat due to a 2% increase in average net sales price, offset
	by a 2% decrease in sales volume.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	In Australia, the Scyon&#153; product range continues to build momentum with fiscal year 2009 sales
	volumes up 47% compared to fiscal year 2008. Scyon differentiated products now represent 10.7% of
	sales, up from 7.5% in fiscal year 2008. Growth has been particularly strong for Scyon Stria&#153;
	cladding and Scyon Secura&#153; external flooring released during fiscal year 2009. An increased share
	of the residential market was achieved by increasing the volume of differentiated James Hardie
	products used in individual homes. Core products also regained volume in the face of increased
	competition, although revenue was affected by low-priced imports. For fiscal year 2009, the
	Australian Bureau of Statistics reported total dwelling unit approvals of 134,499 units, down 14%
	from 156,697 unit approvals for fiscal year 2008. Sales in the multi-unit sector also remained
	depressed as the lack of available credit and general economic uncertainty led to a reduction in
	investment through the second half of calendar year 2008. While some cost improvements have been
	achieved, these have been largely offset by increases in some input costs resulting from a
	depreciating Australian dollar and from lower production volumes and higher utility costs. In New
	Zealand, residential construction continues to decline, with total residential approvals for fiscal
	year 2009 down 34% to 16,200 units compared to fiscal year 2008. The New Zealand business continued
	to out-perform the market by growing sales of its differentiated range of products, including
	Linea
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: TEXT-TOP">
	TM
</SUP>
	weatherboards, the Horizon
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: TEXT-TOP">
	TM
</SUP>
	wall lining and HomeRAB
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: TEXT-TOP">
	TM
</SUP>
	preclad lining which was launched during fiscal year 2009. Sales of these differentiated products
	now account for almost half of sales volume. The Philippines business reported lower sales volumes
	and revenue as a result of a softening domestic market, and export volumes affected by the global
	slow down and pricing pressures stemming from Asian currencies&#146; depreciation against the U.S.
	dollar. The Philippines business continues to seek avenues for volume growth and to establish a
	lower cost base.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<I>
	Gross Profit
</I>
	. Gross profit decreased 27% from $530.0&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2008 to $388.8&nbsp;million
	in fiscal year 2009. The gross profit margin decreased
	3.8&nbsp;percentage points from 36.1% in fiscal
	year 2008 to 32.3% in fiscal year 2009.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	USA and Europe Fiber Cement gross profit decreased 29% compared to fiscal year 2008 due to lower
	sales volume and higher average unit costs. The gross profit margin of our USA and Europe Fiber
	Cement business decreased 4.1&nbsp;percentage points in fiscal year 2009.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Asia Pacific Fiber Cement gross profit decreased 15% compared to fiscal year 2008. Unfavorable
	currency exchange rate movements in the Asia Pacific business&#146; currencies compared to the U.S.
	dollar accounted for 8% of this decrease while the underlying Australian dollar business results
	accounted for the remaining 7% decrease. The gross profit margin of our Asia Pacific Fiber Cement
	business decreased 2.0&nbsp;percentage points in fiscal year 2009. In Australian dollars, gross profit
	decreased 7% in fiscal year 2009 primarily due to reduced gross profit performance in New Zealand
	driven by lower sales volumes.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<I>
	Selling, General and Administrative (SG&#038;A) Expenses
</I>
	. SG&#038;A expenses decreased 9% from $228.2&nbsp;million
	in fiscal year 2008 to $208.8&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2009, primarily due to lower SG&#038;A spending in
	our USA and Europe Fiber Cement and Asia Pacific Fiber Cement segments, partially offset by higher
	general corporate costs. However, as a percentage of sales, SG&#038;A expense increased 1.9&nbsp;percentage
	points to 17.4% in fiscal year 2009. For fiscal year 2009, SG&#038;A expenses include non-claims
	handling related operating expenses of the AICF of $0.7&nbsp;million.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	56
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage59"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#A52931E20VF_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<U>
	ASIC Proceedings
</U>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	On April&nbsp;23, 2009, Justice Gzell delivered judgment in the civil proceedings commenced by ASIC in
	February&nbsp;2007 in the Supreme Court of New South Wales against us, a former related entity JHIL, now
	ABN 60, and ten former directors and officers.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	As against us, Justice Gzell found that:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	we did not comply with section 1041E of Australia&#146;s Corporations Act 2001 (Cth)
	(&#147;Act&#148;) (false or misleading statements) and section 1041H of the Act (misleading
	or deceptive conduct) by delivering a set of slides to the ASX in June&nbsp;2002 that
	referred to the creation and funding of the Foundation by ABN&nbsp;60 in February&nbsp;2001,
	and
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	we did not comply with section 674(2) of the Act (continuous disclosure) in the
	period&nbsp;March&nbsp;25 to June&nbsp;30, 2003 in not disclosing the transfer of JHIL out of the
	James Hardie Group.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	However, Justice Gzell dismissed the remaining allegations made by ASIC against us in relation to
	statements made by our former CEO, Mr.&nbsp;Macdonald, in Edinburgh and London in June&nbsp;2002.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Justice Gzell also made findings against ABN 60 and each of the former directors and officers
	(details of which may be obtained from ASIC&#146;s website), but also dismissed several allegations made
	by ASIC against these parties.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	There will be a further hearing in late July&nbsp;2009 in relation to exoneration and penalties, which
	may involve further evidence. Orders as to costs and penalties are expected to be entered at the
	conclusion of this process.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	ASIC expenses are included in SG&#038;A expenses. For fiscal years 2009 and 2008, we incurred legal
	costs related to the ASIC proceedings of $14.0&nbsp;million and $5.5&nbsp;million, respectively. Our net
	costs in relation to the ASIC proceedings from February&nbsp;2007 to March&nbsp;31, 2009 total $19.7&nbsp;million.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	See Note 13 to our consolidated financial statements in Item&nbsp;18 and Item&nbsp;3, &#147;Key Information &#151; Risk
	Factors.&#148;
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<U>
	Chile Litigation
</U>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	On April&nbsp;24, 2009 a trial court in Santiago, Chile awarded damages in the equivalent of $13.4
	million against FC Volcan, the former James Hardie Chilean entity, in civil litigation brought by
	Cementa in 2007. FC Volcan is appealing the decision to the Santiago Court of Appeal.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Cementa, a fiber cement manufacturer in Chile, commenced anti-trust proceedings in 2003 against FC
	Volcan, alleging that it had engaged in predatory pricing, by selling products below cost when it
	entered the Chilean market, in breach of the relevant anti-trust laws in Chile. Another fiber
	cement manufacturer in Chile, Quimel, also joined the proceedings.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	As these actions existed prior to the sale of our Chilean business in July&nbsp;2005, we have agreed to
	indemnify the buyer, subject to certain conditions and limitations, for damages or penalties
	awarded against FC Volcan in relation to such proceedings, and we retained conduct of the defense
	of the matters.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	After the anti-trust proceedings concluded in 2006, Cementa, in 2007, brought a separate civil
	action against FC Volcan claiming that Cementa had suffered damages, allegedly as a result of
	predatory pricing. This action resulted in the $13.4&nbsp;million damages award, which is now the
	subject of the appeal by FC Volcan.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Quimel also filed a separate civil action against FC Volcan in 2007, claiming that it had suffered
	damages, allegedly as a result of predatory pricing.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	We denied and continue to deny the allegations of predatory pricing in Chile. We retained conduct
	of the appeal of the two civil damages matters. We intend to vigorously pursue all appellate and
	other alternatives as we do not
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	57
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage60"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#A52931E20VF_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	concur
	with the decision of the trial court. We also intend to exercise our rights under the
	indemnification provisions, including applicable conditions and limitations.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	As of March&nbsp;31, 2009, we believe that we have adequately provided for this contingency as required
	under SFAS No.&nbsp;5.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	See Note 13 to our consolidated financial statements in Item&nbsp;18.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<I>
	Research and Development Expenses
</I>
	. Research and development expenses include costs associated with
	&#147;core&#148; research projects that are designed to benefit all business units. These costs are recorded
	in the Research and Development segment rather than being attributed to individual business units.
	These costs were 20% lower at $14.4&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2009 compared to fiscal year 2008. Other
	research and development costs associated with commercialization projects in business units are
	included in the business unit segment results. In total, these costs were 1% higher at $9.4&nbsp;million
	in fiscal year 2009.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<I>
	Asbestos Adjustments.
</I>
	The asbestos adjustments are derived from an estimate of future Australian
	asbestos-related liabilities in accordance with the Amended FFA that was signed with the NSW
	Government on November&nbsp;21, 2006 and approved by our security holders on February&nbsp;7, 2007.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	The asbestos-related assets and liabilities are denominated in Australian dollars. Therefore the
	reported value of these asbestos-related assets and liabilities in our consolidated balance sheets
	in U.S. dollars is subject to adjustment, with a corresponding effect on our consolidated statement
	of operations, depending on the closing exchange rate between the two currencies at the balance
	sheet date. We receive an updated actuarial estimate as of March&nbsp;31 each year. The last actuarial
	assessment was performed as of March&nbsp;31, 2009.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	The asbestos adjustments for the fiscal years ended March&nbsp;31, 2009 and 2008 are as follows:
</DIV>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<I>
	Operating Income (Loss).
</I>
	Operating income improved from a loss of $36.6&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2008
	to income of $173.6&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2009. Operating income in fiscal year 2009 includes net
	favorable asbestos adjustments of $17.4&nbsp;million and AICF SG&#038;A expenses of $0.7&nbsp;million. In fiscal
	year 2008, operating loss includes net unfavorable asbestos adjustments of $240.1&nbsp;million and AICF
	SG&#038;A expenses of $4.0&nbsp;million.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	USA and Europe Fiber Cement operating income decreased 15% from $235.2&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2008
	to $199.3&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2009, primarily due to reduced gross profit performance in the
	U.S., which resulted from lower sales volume and higher average unit manufacturing costs. The
	higher average unit manufacturing costs were the result of fixed costs being absorbed over
	significantly reduced volumes. As discussed above, fiscal year 2008 includes impairment charges of
	$71.0&nbsp;million. The operating income margin in fiscal year 2009 increased by 1.3&nbsp;percentage points
	to 21.4%.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Asia Pacific Fiber Cement operating income decreased 6% from $50.3&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2008 to
	$47.1&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2009. The unfavorable currency exchange rate movements in the Asia
	Pacific business&#146; currencies compared to the U.S. dollar accounted for a 10% decrease, partially
	offset by a 4% increase in the underlying Australian dollar business results. In Australian
	dollars, Asia Pacific Fiber Cement operating income for fiscal year 2009 increased 4% due to
	decreased SG&#038;A expenses, partially offset by lower gross margin performance. The operating income
	margin was 0.3&nbsp;percentage points higher at 17.2% for fiscal year 2009.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<I>
	General Corporate Costs
</I>
	. General corporate costs increased by $7.4&nbsp;million from $63.9&nbsp;million in
	fiscal year 2008 to $71.3&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2009. The increase was primarily due to higher
	costs associated with the ASIC proceedings and additional legal provisions, partially offset by
	reduced general corporate cost spending as management continues to focus on cost reductions.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	58
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>

<P>
<A NAME="eolPage61"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#A52931E20VF_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<I>
	Net Interest (Expense) Income.
</I>
	Net interest moved from income of $1.1&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2008
	to an expense of $3.0&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2009. The movement was primarily due to higher
	interest expense due to higher average debt and reduced interest income earned by the AICF due to
	lower average investment and cash balances held.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<I>
	Other Expense.
</I>
	As disclosed in Note 2 of our consolidated financial statements in Item&nbsp;18, we are
	required to consolidate the AICF and to present the AICF&#146;s results in compliance with U.S. GAAP.
	Specifically as it relates to the treatment of unrealized losses on investments, we must assess
	whether an investment is other-than-temporarily impaired.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	The AICF invested a portion of the initial funding contribution from us in February&nbsp;2007, by
	acquiring units in managed funds. During the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2009 and 2008, the units
	decreased in value A$13.1&nbsp;million ($10.4&nbsp;million) and A$5.1&nbsp;million ($4.4&nbsp;million), respectively.
	None of the units have been sold, and thus from a commercial perspective the impairment in value
	remains unrealized.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	At March&nbsp;31, 2008, we recorded the A$5.1&nbsp;million ($4.4&nbsp;million) decrease in investment value as
	unrealized under U.S. GAAP and thus did not take a charge to the Consolidated Statement of
	Operations, but rather recorded the loss in equity as a component of other comprehensive income. At
	March&nbsp;31, 2008, we did not consider the investments to be other-than-temporarily impaired. However,
	at March&nbsp;31, 2009, we determined that the decrease in the investment value totaling A$18.2&nbsp;million
	($14.8&nbsp;million) was other-than-temporary and as prescribed by U.S. GAAP recorded this decrease in
	investment value as a charge to the Consolidated Statement of Operations in the line item
<I>
	Other
	Expense
</I>
	.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<I>
	Income Tax Expense.
</I>
	Income tax expense decreased from $36.1&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2008 to $19.5
	million in fiscal year 2009. Income tax expense in fiscal year 2009 includes a tax benefit related
	to asbestos adjustments of $48.7&nbsp;million and unfavorable tax adjustments of $7.2&nbsp;million related to
	FIN 48 adjustments. Income tax expense in fiscal year 2008 includes a tax benefit related to
	asbestos adjustments of $45.8&nbsp;million; a tax benefit related to asset impairments of $27.6&nbsp;million;
	and unfavorable tax adjustments of $5.8&nbsp;million related to FIN 48 adjustments
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<I>
	Net Income (Loss).
</I>
	Net income (loss)&nbsp;moved from a net loss of $71.6&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2008 to
	net income of $136.3&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2009. Net income in fiscal year 2009 includes favorable
	asbestos adjustments of $17.4&nbsp;million; loss on AICF investments of $14.8&nbsp;million; a tax benefit
	related to asbestos adjustments of $48.7&nbsp;million; ASIC expenses of $14.0&nbsp;million ($10.4&nbsp;million,
	after tax); and unfavorable tax adjustments of $7.2&nbsp;million related to FIN 48 adjustments. Net loss
	in fiscal year 2008 includes unfavorable asbestos adjustments of $240.1&nbsp;million; a tax benefit
	related to asbestos adjustments of $45.8&nbsp;million; ASIC expenses of $5.5&nbsp;million ($4.1&nbsp;million,
	after tax); unfavorable tax adjustments of $5.8&nbsp;million related to FIN 48 adjustments; and
	impairment charges of $71.0&nbsp;million ($44.6&nbsp;million, after tax).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Year Ended March&nbsp;31, 2008 Compared to Year Ended March&nbsp;31, 2007
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<I>
	Total Net Sales
</I>
	. Total net sales decreased 5% from $1,542.9&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2007 to $1,468.8
	million in fiscal year 2008. Net sales from USA and Europe Fiber Cement decreased 9% from $1,291.2
	million in fiscal year 2007 to $1,170.5&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2008 due to reduced sales volume,
	partially offset by a higher average net sales price. Net sales from Asia Pacific Fiber Cement
	increased 19% from $251.7&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2007 to $298.3&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2008 due to
	favorable currency exchange rates, increased sales volumes and a higher average net sales price.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<I>
	USA and Europe Fiber Cement Net Sales
</I>
	. Net sales decreased 9% from $1,291.2&nbsp;million in fiscal year
	2007 to $1,170.5&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2008 due to decreased sales volume, partially offset by a
	higher average net sales price. Sales volume decreased 12% from 2,216.2 mmsf in fiscal year 2007 to
	1,951.2 mmsf in fiscal year 2008, as the decline in housing construction activity and deteriorating
	economic conditions led to weaker demand for our products. The average net sales price increased 3%
	from $583 per msf in fiscal year 2007 to $600 per msf in fiscal year 2008 due to price increases
	and a shift in the product mix.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Despite improved housing affordability as a result of further interest rate cuts, the housing
	market in the United States continued to deteriorate during fiscal year 2008 as weaker consumer
	confidence, tighter lending standards and falling housing prices weighed heavily on demand for new
	homes. In the United States, housing construction starts
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	59
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage62"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#A52931E20VF_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	for fiscal year 2008 were at near record lows as builders again attempted to reduce high inventory
	levels of new homes for sale, and as increased foreclosures placed more existing homes on the
	market.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Artisan&#174; Lap, the business&#146; new premium exterior product launched in Atlanta last September, is
	continuing to be well received by architects, developers and builders who work in the custom home
	segment of the market. Artisan&#174; Lap has now been launched in regions of the Western and Southern
	Divisions of the United States.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Repair and remodelling activity in the United States has not been affected to the same extent as
	the new construction segment of the housing market, however some weakness in repair and remodelling
	activity has led to sales of our interior products being slightly lower in fiscal year 2008
	compared to fiscal year 2007.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	The overall rate of market penetration in the United Stated slowed during fiscal year 2008 and the
	business did not buffer the impact of the downturn in housing construction activity to the extent
	expected. The usual seasonal pickup in demand that was expected during the latter part of the
	fourth quarter of fiscal year 2008 did not occur and this led to inventory levels for the business
	at the end of the fiscal year 2008 being higher than expected.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Although the fiber cement business in the United States is continuing to perform well at the
	operating income line relative to other participants in the housing sector, the business has
	shifted its focus for the next fiscal year to increase margins. We believe that this shift in focus
	will not result in funding cuts for key growth initiatives.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	For fiscal year 2008, market penetration in the interior and exterior product categories and an
	increase in the average net sales price helped to partly offset the unfavorable impact of
	significantly weaker housing construction activity in the United States.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	In our U.S. pipes business, net sales decreased in fiscal year 2008 as compared to fiscal year 2007
	due to materially lower sales volume resulting from weaker residential and non-residential
	construction activity in Florida. On May&nbsp;22, 2008, we announced plans to cease production in our
	U.S. pipes business.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	In our Europe Fiber Cement business, net sales continued to grow steadily in fiscal year 2008.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<I>
	Asia Pacific Fiber Cement Net Sales
</I>
	. Net sales increased 19% from $251.7&nbsp;million in fiscal year
	2007 to $298.3&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2008 due to a 17% increase in the average net sales price and
	2% increase in sales volumes from 390.8 mmsf to 398.2 mmsf. Favorable currency exchange rates of
	the Asia Pacific business&#146; currencies compared to the U.S. dollar accounted for 15% of the increase
	in net sales in U.S. dollars. In Australian dollars, net sales increased 4% due to a 2% increase in
	sales volume and a 2% increase in the average Australian dollar net sales price.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	In fiscal year 2008 there was a stronger primary demand for fiber cement in Australia and New
	Zealand mainly due to growth in sales of the Scyon&#153; product range in Australia and Linea&#153;
	weatherboards in New Zealand, a higher average net sales price and favorable foreign currency
	movements. In Australia, sales of Scyon&#153; branded differentiated products continued to grow and
	increased as a proportion of the sales mix. Sales of Scyon&#153; branded products for fiscal year 2008
	increased 150% compared to fiscal year 2007. Non-differentiated products remain subject to strong
	price competition. In New Zealand, differentiated products, including Linea&#153; weatherboards also
	continued to grow as a proportion of the sales mix. The increase in the average net sales price in
	fiscal year 2008 was due to the shift in the Australia and New Zealand sales mix.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<I>
	Gross Profit
</I>
	. Gross profit decreased 8% from $573.0&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2007 to $530.0&nbsp;million
	in fiscal year 2008. The gross profit margin decreased 1.0&nbsp;percentage point from 37.1% in fiscal
	year 2007 to 36.1% in fiscal year 2008.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	USA and Europe Fiber Cement gross profit decreased 12% compared to fiscal year 2007 due to lower
	sales volumes, higher freight costs and higher average unit costs, partially offset by a higher
	average net sales price. The gross profit margin decreased 1.2&nbsp;percentage points in fiscal year
	2008.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Asia Pacific Fiber Cement gross profit increased 24% compared to fiscal year 2007. Favorable
	currency exchange rates of the Asia Pacific business&#146; currencies compared to the U.S. dollar
	accounted for 14% of this increase while the underlying Australian dollar business results
	accounted for the remaining 10% increase. In Australian dollars,
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	60
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage63"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#A52931E20VF_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	gross profit increased 10% in fiscal year 2008 due to increased sales volumes, a higher average net
	sales price and an insurance claim recovery which accounted for 2% of the increase. The gross
	profit margin increased 1.4&nbsp;percentage points in fiscal year 2008.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<I>
	Selling, General and Administrative (SG&#038;A) Expenses
</I>
	. SG&#038;A expenses increased 6% from $214.6&nbsp;million
	in fiscal year 2007 to $228.2&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2008, primarily due to higher warranty
	provisions relating to non-U.S. activities, costs associated with the ASIC proceedings, non-claims
	handling related operating expenses of the AICF and the impact of the unfavorable currency exchange
	rates of the Asia Pacific business&#146; currencies compared to the U.S. dollar. These increases were
	partially offset by improved SG&#038;A performance of the USA and Europe Fiber Cement segment. As a
	percentage of sales, SG&#038;A expense increased 1.6&nbsp;percentage points to 15.5% in fiscal year 2008.
	SG&#038;A expenses in fiscal year 2008 include non-claims handling related operating expenses of the
	AICF of $4.0&nbsp;million.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<U>
	ASIC Proceedings
</U>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	See
	&#147;Year Ended March 31, 2009 compared to Year Ended March 31,
	2008&#148; above for discussion of the ASIC proceedings.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<I>
	Research and Development Expenses
</I>
	. Research and development expenses include costs associated with
	&#147;core&#148; research projects that are designed to benefit all business units. These costs are recorded
	in the Research and Development segment rather than being attributed to individual business units.
	These costs were 38% higher at $18.0&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2008. Other research and development
	costs associated with commercialization projects in business units are included in the business
	unit segment results. In total, these costs were 28% lower at $9.3&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2008.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<I>
	Impairment Charges.
</I>
	The downturn in U.S. construction activity has prompted us to review the
	carrying value of certain long-lived assets. As a result of these reviews, impairment charges of
	$71.0&nbsp;million have been taken in fiscal year 2008.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	On October&nbsp;31, 2007, we announced plans to suspend production at our Blandon, Pennsylvania plant in
	the United States. We recorded an asset impairment of $32.4&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2008 in our USA
	and Europe Fiber Cement segment. The impaired assets include buildings and machinery, which were
	reduced to their estimated fair value based on valuation methods including quoted market prices and
	discounted future cash flows. These assets are being held for use by us. Since the date of the
	announcement through March&nbsp;31, 2008, we have incurred $1.4&nbsp;million of closure costs. These closure
	costs are not included in the impairment charge of $32.4&nbsp;million and have been included in cost of
	goods sold and selling, general and administrative expenses in the period in which they were
	incurred.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	On May&nbsp;22, 2008, we announced plans to cease production at our Plant City, Florida Hardie Pipe
	manufacturing facility in the United States. As a result, we recorded an asset impairment of $25.4
	million in fiscal year 2008 in our USA and Europe Fiber Cement segment. The impaired assets include
	buildings and machinery, which were reduced to their estimated fair value based on valuation
	methods including quoted market prices and discounted future cash flows.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	We recorded an asset impairment of $13.2&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2008 related to buildings and
	machinery utilized to produce materials for our products. This impairment charge was recorded in
	our USA and Europe Fiber Cement segment. The impaired assets were reduced to their estimated fair
	value based on valuation methods including quoted market prices and discounted future cash flows.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	61
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<I>
	SCI and Other Related Expenses
</I>
	. During fiscal year 2008, SCI and other related expenses were nil
	compared to $13.6&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2007. Now that the Amended FFA has been implemented, we
	anticipate no significant SCI and other related expenses going forward.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<I>
	Asbestos Adjustments.
</I>
	The asbestos adjustments are derived from an estimate of future Australian
	asbestos-related liabilities in accordance with the Amended FFA that was signed with the NSW
	Government on November&nbsp;21, 2006 and approved by our security holders on February&nbsp;7, 2007.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	The asbestos-related assets and liabilities are denominated in Australian dollars. Therefore the
	reported value of these asbestos-related assets and liabilities in our consolidated balance sheets
	in U.S. dollars is subject to adjustment, with a corresponding effect on our consolidated statement
	of operations, depending on the closing exchange rate between the two currencies at the balance
	sheet date.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	The asbestos adjustments for the fiscal years ended March&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007 are as follows:
</DIV>

</DIV>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<I>
	Operating Loss.
</I>
	Operating loss decreased from $86.6&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2007 to $36.6&nbsp;million in
	fiscal year 2008. Operating loss in fiscal year 2008 includes net unfavorable asbestos adjustments
	of $240.1&nbsp;million, AICF SG&#038;A expenses of $4.0&nbsp;million and asset impairments of $71.0&nbsp;million. In
	fiscal year 2007, operating loss includes net unfavorable asbestos adjustments of $405.5&nbsp;million.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	USA and Europe Fiber Cement operating income decreased 33% from $353.1&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2007
	to $235.2&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2008, primarily due to impairment charges, lower volume and higher
	freight costs, partially offset by lower SG&#038;A spending. The operating income margin in fiscal year
	2008 was lower by 7.2&nbsp;percentage points at 20.1%.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Asia Pacific Fiber Cement operating income for fiscal year 2008 increased 28% from $39.4&nbsp;million in
	fiscal year 2007 to $50.3&nbsp;million. Favorable currency exchange rates of the Asia Pacific business&#146;
	currencies compared to the U.S. dollar accounted for 16% of this increase while the underlying
	Australian dollar business results accounted for the remaining 12% increase. In Australian dollars,
	Asia Pacific Fiber Cement operating income for fiscal year 2008 increased 12% due to an improved
	gross margin performance partially offset by increased SG&#038;A expenses. The operating income margin
	was 1.2&nbsp;percentage points higher at 16.9% for fiscal year 2008.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<I>
	General Corporate Costs
</I>
	. General corporate costs increased by $7.4&nbsp;million from $56.5&nbsp;million in
	fiscal year 2007 to $63.9&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2008. The increase was primarily due to AICF SG&#038;A
	costs of $4.0&nbsp;million, higher warranty provisions relating to non-U.S. activities and costs
	associated with the ASIC proceedings, partially offset by the decrease in SCI costs.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<I>
	Net Interest Income (Expense).
</I>
	Net interest income (expense)&nbsp;increased from an expense of $6.5
	million in fiscal year 2007 to income of $1.1&nbsp;million. The increase was primarily due to interest
	income of $9.4&nbsp;million earned on investments and cash balances held by the AICF and the lack of a
	make-whole payment in fiscal year 2008 compared to the $6.0&nbsp;million make-whole payment made in
	fiscal year 2007. These increases were partially offset by reduced capitalized interest and reduced
	interest income due to lower cash balances.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<I>
	Income Tax (Expense) Benefit.
</I>
	Income tax decreased from an income tax benefit of $243.9&nbsp;million in
	fiscal year 2007 to an income tax expense of $36.1&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2008. Income tax expense
	in fiscal year 2008 includes a tax benefit related to asbestos adjustments of $45.8&nbsp;million; a tax
	benefit related to asset impairments of $27.6&nbsp;million; and unfavorable tax adjustments of $5.8
	million related to FIN 48 adjustments. Income tax expense in fiscal
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	62
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>

<A NAME="eolPage65"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#A52931E20VF_HTM_TOCPAGE">

</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	year 2007 includes a tax benefit related to asbestos adjustments of $335.0&nbsp;million and a favorable
	tax adjustment of $10.4&nbsp;million related to tax provision write-backs.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	With effect from April&nbsp;1, 2007, we were required to adopt the provisions of FIN 48, &#147;Accounting for
	Uncertainty in Income Taxes, an interpretation of SFAS No.&nbsp;109, Accounting for Income Taxes.&#148; The
	adoption of FIN 48 resulted in the reduction of our consolidated beginning retained earnings of
	$78.0&nbsp;million.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	See Note 14 to our consolidated financial statements in Item&nbsp;18 for further information on the
	adoption of FIN 48.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<I>
	Net (Loss) Income.
</I>
	Net income decreased from a net income of $151.7&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2007 to
	a net loss of $71.6&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2008. Net loss in fiscal year 2008 includes asbestos
	adjustments of $240.1&nbsp;million; a tax benefit related to asbestos adjustments of $45.8&nbsp;million;
	impairment charges of $71.0&nbsp;million ($44.6&nbsp;million, after tax); and unfavorable tax adjustments of
	$5.8&nbsp;million related to FIN 48 adjustments. Net income in fiscal year 2007 includes asbestos
	adjustments of $405.5&nbsp;million and a tax benefit related to the implementation of the Amended FFA of
	$335.0&nbsp;million. Also included in net income for fiscal year 2007 are SCI and other related expenses
	of $13.6&nbsp;million ($12.6&nbsp;million, after tax), the make-whole payment on the prepayment on notes of
	$6.0&nbsp;million ($5.6&nbsp;million after tax) and a tax provision write back of $10.4&nbsp;million.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	Impact of Recent Accounting Pronouncements
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<B>
<I>
	Business Combinations
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	In December&nbsp;2007, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;141 (revised 2007), &#147;Business Combinations&#148; (which we
	refer to as SFAS No.&nbsp;141R), which replaces SFAS No.&nbsp;141. The statement establishes principles and
	requirements for how the acquirer in a business combination recognizes and measures in its
	financial statements the identifiable assets acquired, the liabilities assumed, and any controlling
	interest; recognizes and measures the goodwill acquired in the business combination or a gain from
	a bargain purchase; and determines what information to disclose to enable users of the financial
	statements to evaluate the nature and financial effects of the business combination. The provisions
	of SFAS No.&nbsp;141R are effective for us for business combinations for which the acquisition date is
	on or after April&nbsp;1, 2009. The adoption of SFAS No 141R will not have a material impact on our
	financial statements unless acquisitions are made.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Noncontrolling Interests in Consolidated Financial Statements &#150; an amendment to ARB No.&nbsp;51
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	In December&nbsp;2007, the FASB approved the issuance of SFAS No.&nbsp;160 &#147;Noncontrolling Interests in
	Consolidated Financial Statements &#150; an amendment to ARB No.&nbsp;51&#148; (which we refer to as SFAS No.
	160). SFAS No.&nbsp;160 establishes accounting and reporting standards that require the ownership
	interest in subsidiaries held by parties other than the entity be clearly identified and presented
	in the Consolidated Balance Sheets within equity, but separate from the entity&#146;s equity; the amount
	of consolidated net income attributable to the entity and the noncontrolling interest be clearly
	identified and presented on the face of the Consolidated Statement of Earnings; and changes in the
	entity&#146;s ownership interest while the entity retains its controlling financial interest in its
	subsidiary be accounted for consistently. The provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;160 are effective for us on
	April&nbsp;1, 2009. The adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;160 is not expected to have a material impact on our
	financial statements.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Disclosures about Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	In March&nbsp;2008, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;161, &#147;Disclosures about Derivative Instruments and Hedging
	Activities&#148; (which we refer to as SFAS No.&nbsp;161). SFAS No.&nbsp;161 is intended to improve financial
	reporting of derivative instruments and hedging activities by requiring enhanced disclosures to
	enable investors to better understand their effects on an entity&#146;s financial position, financial
	performance, and cash flows. SFAS No.&nbsp;161 is effective for us on April&nbsp;1, 2009. The adoption of
	SFAS No.&nbsp;161 is not expected to have a material impact on our financial statements.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<B>
<I>
	Hierarchy of Generally Accepted Accounting Principles
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	In May&nbsp;2008, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;162 &#147;The Hierarchy of Generally Accepted Accounting
	Principles&#148; (which we refer to as SFAS No.&nbsp;162)
<I>
	.
</I>
	SFAS No.&nbsp;162 identifies the sources of accounting
	principles and the framework for selecting the principles used in the preparation of financial
	statements of nongovernmental entities
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	63
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>

<A NAME="eolPage66"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#A52931E20VF_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	that are presented in conformity with U.S. GAAP. This statement shall be effective 60&nbsp;days
	following the Securities Exchange and Commission&#146;s approval of the Public Company Accounting
	Oversight Board amendments to AU Section&nbsp;411, &#147;The Meaning of Present Fairly in Conformity With
	Generally Accepted Accounting Principles.&#148; The adoption of SFAS 162 is not expected to have a
	material impact on our financial statements.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	Liquidity and Capital Resources
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Our treasury policy regarding our liquidity management, foreign exchange risks management, interest
	rate risk management and cash management is administered by our treasury department and is
	centralized in The Netherlands. This policy is reviewed annually and is designed to ensure that we
	have sufficient liquidity to support our business activities and meet future business requirements
	in the countries in which we operate. Counterparty limits are managed by our treasury department
	and based upon the counterparty credit rating; total exposure to any one counterparty is limited to
	specified amounts and signed off annually by the Chief Financial Officer.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	We have historically met our working capital needs and capital expenditure requirements through a
	combination of cash flow from operations, proceeds from the divestiture of businesses, credit
	facilities and other borrowings, proceeds from the sale of property, plant and equipment, and
	proceeds from the redemption of investments. Seasonal fluctuations in working capital generally
	have not had a significant impact on our short-term or long-term liquidity. We anticipate that we
	will have sufficient funds to meet our planned working capital and other cash requirements for the
	next 12&nbsp;months based on our existing cash balances and anticipated operating cash flows arising
	during the year. We anticipate that any additional cash requirements will be met from existing
	cash, unutilized committed facilities, anticipated future net operating cash flows and proposed new
	facilities.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Excluding restricted cash, we had cash and cash equivalents of $42.4&nbsp;million as of March&nbsp;31, 2009.
	At that date, we also had credit facilities totaling $498.3&nbsp;million, of which $324.0&nbsp;million was
	drawn. The credit facilities are all uncollateralized and consist of the following:
</DIV>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_20"></A>

<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	At March&nbsp;31, 2009 we had net debt of $281.6&nbsp;million, compared with net debt of $229.1&nbsp;million at
	March&nbsp;31, 2008.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Our credit facilities as of March&nbsp;31, 2009 consist of 364-day facilities in the amount of $68.3
	million and $50.0&nbsp;million, which as of March&nbsp;31, 2009, mature in June&nbsp;2009 and November&nbsp;2009,
	respectively. We are aware that
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->

<!-- /FOLIO -->
