<P>
<A NAME="eolPage80"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#A52931E20VF_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Continuous Disclosure and Market Communication
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	We strive to comply with all relevant disclosure laws and listing rules in Australia (ASX and
	ASIC), the United States (SEC and NYSE) and The Netherlands (AFM).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Our Continuous Disclosure and Market Communication Policy aims to ensure that investors can easily
	understand our strategies, assess the quality of our management and examine our financial position
	and the strength of our growth prospects, and that we comply with all of our legal disclosure
	obligations.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	The Managing Board is responsible for ensuring we comply with our continuous disclosure
	obligations. A Disclosure Committee comprised of the Managing Board and the Vice President Investor
	and Media Relations is responsible for all decisions regarding our market disclosure obligations
	outside of our normal financial reporting calendar. For our quarterly and annual results releases,
	the Managing Board is supported by the Financial Statements Disclosure Committee, which provides
	assurance regarding our compliance with reporting processes and controls. The Managing Board
	discusses with the Audit Committee any issues arising out of meetings of the Financial Statements
	Disclosure Committee that affect the quarterly and annual results releases. The Audit Committee
	reviewed our disclosure practices under the Continuous Disclosure and Market Communication policy
	during fiscal year 2009.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Share Trading
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	All of our employees and directors are subject to our Insider Trading Policy. Our employees and
	directors may only buy or sell our securities within four weeks beginning two days after the
	announcement of quarterly or full year results, or another period designated by the Supervisory
	Board for this purpose, provided they are not in possession of price sensitive information.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	There are additional restrictions on trading for designated senior employees and directors,
	including a requirement that they receive prior clearance from our compliance officer before
	trading or pledging their shares by taking out a margin loan over them, and a general prohibition
	on hedging or selling any shares or options for short-swing profit. Our employees who are not
	designated employees may hedge vested options or shares, provided they notify us.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	The Managing Board recognizes that it is the individual responsibility of each of our directors and
	employees to ensure he or she complies with the spirit and the letter of insider trading laws and
	that notification to the compliance officer in no way implies approval of any transaction.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	Risk Management
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<B>
<I>
	Overall Responsibility
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	The Audit Committee has oversight of our risk management policies, procedures and controls. The
	Audit Committee reviews, monitors and discusses these matters with the Managing Board. The Audit
	Committee and Managing Board report periodically to the Supervisory Board on our risk management
	policies, processes and controls.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	The Audit Committee is supported in its oversight role by the policies put in place by the Managing
	Board to oversee and manage material business risks, as well as the roles played by the Risk
	Management Committee (described in detail below) and internal and external audit functions. The
	internal and external audit functions are separate from and independent of each other and each has
	a direct reporting line to the Audit Committee.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Objective
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	We consider that a sound framework of risk management policies, procedures and controls produces a
	system of risk oversight, risk management and internal control that is fundamental to good
	corporate governance and creation of shareholder value. The objective of our risk management
	policies, procedures and controls is to ensure that:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	our risk management systems are effective;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	our principal strategic, operational and financial risks are identified;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	78
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage81"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#A52931E20VF_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	effective systems are in place to monitor and manage risks; and
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	reporting systems, internal controls and arrangements for monitoring compliance with
	laws and regulations are adequate.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Risk management does not involve avoiding all risks. Our risk management policies seek to strike a
	balance between ensuring that we continue to generate financial returns and simultaneously manages
	risks appropriately by setting appropriate strategies and objectives.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Policies for Management of Material Business Risks
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Management has put in place a number of key policies, processes and independent controls to provide
	assurance as to the integrity of our systems of internal control and risk management. In addition
	to the measures described elsewhere in this report, the more significant policies, processes or
	controls we adopted for oversight and management of material business risks are:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	quarterly reporting to the Audit Committee of the Risk Management Committee&#146;s
	assessment of the key strategic, operations, reporting and compliance risks we face,
	the Risk Committee&#146;s assessment of the level of risk and the processes implemented to
	manage each of these key risks over the upcoming 12&nbsp;months;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	an Enterprise Risk Management process, which involves developing contingency plans
	for the key risks we face and our assumptions in our three year strategic plans and
	beyond;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	a planning process involving the preparation of three-year strategic plans and a
	rolling 12&nbsp;month forecast;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	annual budgeting and monthly reporting to monitor performance;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	an internal audit department with a reporting line direct to the Chairman of the
	Audit Committee;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	increased monitoring of our liquidity and status of renewals of finance facilities;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	maintaining an appropriate insurance program;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	maintaining policies and procedures in relation to treasury operations, including
	the use of financial derivatives;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	issuing and revising standards and procedures in relation to environmental and
	health and safety matters;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	implementing and maintaining training programs in relation to legal issues such as
	trade practices/antitrust, trade secrecy, and intellectual property protection;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	issuing procedures requiring significant capital and recurring expenditure to be
	approved at the appropriate levels; and
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	documenting detailed accounting policies, procedures and guidance for the group in a
	single group finance manual.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	A summary of these policies, processes and controls is available in the Investor Relations area of
	our website
<U>
	(www.jameshardie.com)
</U>
	.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	One other example of our approach to managing significant business risks is the establishment of
	the Due Diligence Committee, which was formed to oversee the development of our proposal to move
	our domicile from The Netherlands.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	During fiscal year 2009, the Audit Committee, and through it the Supervisory and Joint Boards,
	received a number of reports on the operation and effectiveness of the policies, processes and
	controls described in this section. This included a review by the Director of Internal Audit of our
	current risk management practices, how they compare with best practices and the steps proposed by
	management to continue cultivating our risk management culture.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Risk Management Committee
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	The Risk Management Committee, which reviews and monitors the risks we face, is the primary
	management forum for risk assessment and risk management. This role is more formally documented in
	our Risk Management Committee charter. The Risk Management Committee comprises a cross-functional
	group of employees and reports
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	79
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage82"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#A52931E20VF_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	quarterly to both the Managing Board and Audit Committee on the procedures in place for
	identifying, monitoring, managing and reporting on the principal strategic, operational, financial
	and legal risks we face. The Risk Management Committee also oversees our Enterprise Risk Management
	process.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Internal Audit
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	The Director of Internal Audit heads the internal audit department. The Internal Audit Charter sets
	out the independence of the internal audit department, its scope of work, responsibilities and
	audit plan. The internal audit department&#146;s workplan is approved annually by the Audit Committee.
	The Director of Internal Audit reports to the Chairman of the Audit Committee and meets quarterly
	with the Audit Committee and Supervisory Board in executive sessions.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	External Audit
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	The external auditor reviews each quarterly and half&#150;year results announcement and audits the full
	year results.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	The external auditor attends each meeting of the Audit Committee, including an executive session
	where only members of the Audit Committee and Supervisory Board directors are present.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	The Audit Committee has approved policies to ensure that all non-audit services performed by the
	external auditor, including the amount of fees payable for those services, receive prior approval.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Financial Statements Disclosure Committee
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	The Financial Statements Disclosure Committee is a management committee comprising our senior
	finance, accounting, compliance, legal, tax, treasury and investor relations executives, which
	meets with the Managing Board prior to the Supervisory Board&#146;s consideration of any quarterly or
	annual results. The Financial Statements Disclosure Committee is a forum for the Managing Board to
	discuss, and, on the basis of those discussions, report to the Audit Committee, about a range of
	risk management procedures, policies and controls, covering the draft results materials, business
	unit financial performance and the current status of legal, tax, treasury, accounting, compliance,
	internal audit, complaints and disclosure control matters.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	Shareholders&#146; Participation
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<B>
<I>
	Listing Information
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	We are a public limited liability company (
<I>
	naamloze vennootschap
</I>
	) incorporated under Dutch law. Our
	securities trade as CUFS on the ASX and as ADSs on the NYSE.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Annual Information Meeting
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Recognizing that most shareholders will not be able to attend the AGM in The Netherlands, we
	conduct an AIM in Australia so shareholders can review items of business and other matters that
	will be considered and voted on at the AGM.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	We distribute with the Notice of Meetings (for the AIM and the AGM) a question form which
	shareholders can use to submit questions in advance of the AIM. Shareholders can also ask questions
	relevant to the business of the meeting during the AIM.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	For those shareholders unable to attend, the AIM is broadcast live over the internet in the
	Investor Relations area of the website at
<U>
	www.jameshardie.com
</U>
	. The webcast remains on our
	website so it can be replayed later if required. Shareholders are able to appoint representatives
	to attend the AIM on their behalf and ask questions.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	The external auditor attends the AIM by telephone and is available to answer questions.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	80
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>

	The AGM is held in The Netherlands within seven days of the AIM. Each shareholder (other than ADS
	holders) has the right to:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">

	While ADS holders cannot vote directly, ADS holders can direct the voting of their underlying
	shares through the ADS depository.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">

</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Investor Website
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	We have a dedicated section on corporate governance as part of the Investor Relations area of our
	website
<U>
	(www.jameshardie.com)
</U>
	. Information on this section of the website is progressively updated
	and expanded to ensure it presents the most up-to-date information on our corporate governance
	structure. Except where stated, the contents of the website are not incorporated into this annual
	report.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	Compliance with Corporate Governance Requirements
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<B>
<I>
	NYSE Corporate Governance Rules
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	In accordance with the NYSE corporate governance standards, listed companies that are foreign
	private issuers (which includes us) are permitted to follow home-country practice in lieu of the
	provisions of the corporate governance rules contained in Section&nbsp;303A of the Listed Company
	Manual, except that foreign private issuers are required to comply with Section&nbsp;303A.06, Section
	303A.11 and Section&nbsp;303A.12(b) and (c), each of which is discussed below.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Section&nbsp;303A.06 requires that all listed companies have an Audit Committee that satisfies the
	requirements of Rule&nbsp;10A-3 under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Section&nbsp;303A.11 provides that listed foreign private issuers must disclose any significant ways in
	which their corporate governance practices differ from those followed by U.S. companies under the
	NYSE listing standards.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Section&nbsp;303A.12(b) provides that each listed company&#146;s Chief Executive Officer must promptly notify
	the NYSE in writing after any executive officer of the listed company becomes aware of any material
	non-compliance with any applicable provisions of this Section&nbsp;303A. Section&nbsp;303A.12(c) provides
	that each listed company must submit a written affirmation annually to the NYSE about its
	compliance with the NYSE&#146;s corporate governance listing
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	81
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage84"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#A52931E20VF_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	standards and a written interim affirmation to the NYSE upon the occurrence of certain specified
	changes to the Audit Committee.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	We presently comply with the mandatory NYSE listing standards and many of the non-compulsory
	standards including, for example, the requirement that a majority of our directors meet the
	independence requirements of the NYSE.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Two ways in which our corporate governance practices differ significantly from those followed by
	U.S. domestic companies under NYSE listing standards should be noted:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	In the U.S., an audit committee of a public company is required to be directly
	responsible for appointing the company&#146;s independent registered public accounting firm.
	Under Dutch law, the independent registered public accounting firm is appointed by the
	shareholders or, in the absence of such an appointment, by the Supervisory Board and
	then the Managing Board; and
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	NYSE rules require each issuer to have an audit committee, a compensation committee
	(equivalent to a remuneration committee) and a nominating committee composed entirely
	of independent directors. As a foreign private issuer, we do not have to comply with
	this requirement. In our case, the charters of our Board Committees reflect Australian
	and Dutch practices, in that we have a majority of independent directors on these
	committees, unless a higher number is mandatory. Notwithstanding this difference, our
	Supervisory Board has determined that all of the current members of our Audit
	Committee, Remuneration Committee and Nominating and Governance Committee presently
	qualify as independent in accordance with the rules and regulations of the SEC and the
	NYSE.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	Current and Former Directors and Executive Officers
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	The current members of our Supervisory Board, Managing Board, Joint Board and our Senior Leadership
	Team, along with former directors and former Senior Leadership Team officers, are as follows:
</DIV>
</EFX_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS>

<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	Directors
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<B>
<I>
	Michael Hammes
</I>
</B>
	is Chairman of our Joint Board and Supervisory Board. Mr.&nbsp;Hammes was appointed as an
	independent non-executive director of JHI NV at the Extraordinary General Meeting in February&nbsp;2007
	and was appointed Chairman of the Joint and Supervisory Boards in January&nbsp;2008. He has held a
	number of executive positions in the medical products, hardware and home improvement, and
	automobile sectors, including Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of Sunrise Medical, Inc., which
	designs, manufactures and markets home medical equipment worldwide (2000 to 2007). Mr.&nbsp;Hammes is
	currently lead director of Navistar International Corporation (since 1996).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<B>
<I>
	Donald McGauchie
</I>
</B>
	is Deputy Chairman of our Joint Board and Supervisory Board, Chairman of our
	Nominating and Governance Committee and a member of our Remuneration Committee. Mr.&nbsp;McGauchie
	joined JHI NV as an independent, non-executive director in August&nbsp;2003. Mr.&nbsp;McGauchie was Acting
	Deputy Chairman of our Joint and Supervisory Boards from February to March&nbsp;2007. In April&nbsp;2007, Mr.
	McGauchie was appointed Deputy Chairman of our Joint and Supervisory Boards. Mr.&nbsp;McGauchie has wide
	commercial experience within the food processing, commodity trading, finance and telecommunication
	sectors. He also has extensive public policy experience, currently serving as a director of The
	Reserve Bank of Australia and having previously held several high-level advisory positions to the
	Australian Government. Mr.&nbsp;McGauchie is currently a director of Nufarm Limited (since 2003). In
	2003, he was awarded the Centenary Medal for service to Australian society through agriculture and
	business.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<B>
<I>
	Brian Anderson
</I>
</B>
	is a member of our Joint Board and Supervisory Board, Chairman of our Audit
	Committee and a member of our Remuneration Committee. Mr.&nbsp;Anderson was appointed as an independent,
	non-executive director on December&nbsp;14, 2006 after joining JHI NV as a consultant to the Board in
	August&nbsp;2006. He was reelected by our shareholders at our Extraordinary General Meeting in February
	2007. Previously, Mr.&nbsp;Anderson was Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of
	OfficeMax, Inc. from 2004 until 2005 and prior to that he held a variety of
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	83
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage86"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#A52931E20VF_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	senior positions at Baxter International, Inc., including Corporate Vice President of Finance,
	Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer from 1997 until 2004. Mr.&nbsp;Anderson has been an
	accredited Certified Public Accountant since 1976. Mr.&nbsp;Anderson is currently a director of A.M.
	Castle &#038; Co. (since July&nbsp;2005), Pulte Homes Corporation (since September&nbsp;2005) and W.W. Grainger
	(since 1999).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<B>
<I>
	David Harrison
</I>
</B>
	is a member of our Joint Board and Supervisory Board, Chairman of our Remuneration
	Committee and a member of our Nominating and Governance Committee and Audit Committee. Mr.&nbsp;Harrison
	was appointed as an independent non-executive director of JHI NV effective May&nbsp;19, 2008 and
	reelected at our AGM in August&nbsp;2008. Mr.&nbsp;Harrison is an experienced company director and has a
	distinguished finance background, having served with special expertise in corporate finance roles,
	international operations and information technology during his 22&nbsp;years with Borg-Warner General
	Electric Co. He is Managing Partner of the U.S. financial investor, HCI Inc. and previously spent
	ten years at Pentair, Inc., as Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Mr.&nbsp;Harrison
	is currently a director for National Oilwell Varco (since 2003) and Navistar International (since
	2007).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<B>
<I>
	James Osborne
</I>
</B>
	was appointed as an independent non-executive director of JHI NV in March&nbsp;2009. He is
	a member of the Joint and Supervisory Boards and a member of the Audit Committee. Mr.&nbsp;Osborne is
	an experienced company director with a strong legal background and a considerable knowledge of
	international business operating in North America and Europe. His career includes 35&nbsp;years with the
	leading Irish law firm, A&#038;L Goodbody, in roles which included opening the firm&#146;s New York office in
	1979, and serving as the firm&#146;s managing partner for 12&nbsp;years. He has served as a consultant to the
	firm since 1994. Mr.&nbsp;Osborne also contributed to the listing of Ryanair in London, New York and
	Dublin and continues to serve on its board. Mr.&nbsp;Osborne is currently Chairman of Newcourt Group
	plc (since 2004) and a director at Ryanair Holdings plc (since 1996)
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<B>
<I>
	Rudy van der Meer
</I>
</B>
	is a member of our Joint Board and Supervisory Board and Nominating and
	Governance Committee. Mr. van der Meer was appointed as an independent non-executive director of
	JHI NV at the Extraordinary General Meeting in February&nbsp;2007. During his 32&nbsp;year association with
	Akzo Nobel N.V., he held a number of senior positions including Chief Executive Officer &#151; Coatings
	from 2000 to 2005, Chief Executive Officer &#151; Chemicals from 1993 to 2000, member of the five member
	Executive Board from 1993 to 2005, Division
<BR>
	President &#151; Akzo Salt &#038; Base Chemicals from 1991 to
	1993 and member of the Executive Board &#151; Akzo Salt &#038; Base Chemicals from 1989 to 1991. Mr. van der
	Meer is currently a director of Imtech N.V. (since 2005).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<B>
<I>
	Louis Gries
</I>
</B>
	is our Chief Executive Officer and a member of the Joint Board and Chairman of the
	Managing Board. Mr.&nbsp;Gries was elected to the Managing Board by our shareholders at our 2005 AGM.
	Mr.&nbsp;Gries joined us as Manager of the Fontana fiber cement plant in California in February&nbsp;1991 and
	has held a number of roles with us leading to his appointment as Executive Vice President &#151;
	Operations in January&nbsp;2003, responsible for operations, sales and marketing in our businesses in
	the Americas, Asia Pacific and Europe. In October&nbsp;2004, Mr.&nbsp;Gries was appointed interim Chief
	Executive Officer and in February&nbsp;2005, he was appointed Chief Executive Officer. He has held
	management positions with United States Gypsum Corporation, or USG. He has a Bachelor of Science in
	Mathematics from the University of Illinois and an MBA from California State University, Long
	Beach.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<B>
<I>
	Russell Chenu
</I>
</B>
	is our Chief Financial Officer and a member of the Managing Board. Mr.&nbsp;Chenu joined
	us in October&nbsp;2004 as Interim Chief Financial Officer and Executive Vice President, Australia. In
	February&nbsp;2005, he was appointed Chief Financial Officer. Mr.&nbsp;Chenu was elected to our Managing
	Board by our shareholders at our 2005 AGM and re-elected at our AGM in August&nbsp;2008. From February
	2001 to July&nbsp;2004, Mr.&nbsp;Chenu served as Chief Financial Officer of Tab Limited, then a publicly
	traded entertainment and gambling company. Mr.&nbsp;Chenu previously worked for us for 13&nbsp;years in a
	variety of capacities, ultimately as Group Banking Manager from 1982 to 1984. He has a Bachelor of
	Commerce from the University of Melbourne and an MBA from Macquarie Graduate School of Management
	in Australia.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<B>
<I>
	Robert Cox
</I>
</B>
	is our General Counsel, Company Secretary and a member of the Managing Board. Mr.&nbsp;Cox
	joined us in January&nbsp;2008 as General Counsel and became a member of the Managing Board and Company
	Secretary effective May&nbsp;7, 2008. He was re-elected at our AGM in August&nbsp;2008. Prior to joining us,
	Mr.&nbsp;Cox was Vice President, Deputy General Counsel and Assistant Secretary with PepsiCo Inc. for
	five years. His experience also includes 10&nbsp;years as a partner of the international law firm
	Bingham McCutchen LLP, at their offices in Asia and California. Mr.&nbsp;Cox has a Bachelor of Arts from
	Wesleyan University in Connecticut; a Master of Arts from the John Hopkins School of Advanced
	International Studies in Washington, D.C. and a JD from the University of California, Berkeley,
	California.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	84
<!-- /FOLIO -->

<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	Senior Leadership Team Officers
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<B>
<I>
	Mark Fisher
</I>
</B>
	is our Vice President &#151; Research and Development. Mr.&nbsp;Fisher joined us in 1993 as a
	Production Engineer and has held a variety of production, sales and management roles with us. In
	November&nbsp;2004, Mr.&nbsp;Fisher became Vice President &#151; Specialty Products. In December&nbsp;2005, he was
	appointed as Vice President &#151; Research and Development. In February&nbsp;2008, his role was expanded to
	cover Engineering &#038; Process Development. Before joining us, Mr.&nbsp;Fisher worked in engineering for
	Chevron Corporation. Mr.&nbsp;Fisher has a Bachelor of Science in Mechanical Engineering and an MBA from
	University of Southern California.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<B>
<I>
	Grant Gustafson
</I>
</B>
	is our Vice President &#151; International. Mr.&nbsp;Gustafson joined us in April&nbsp;2006 to
	oversee Interiors and Business Development. His role was expanded to cover Marketing, Europe and IT
	in fiscal year 2008 and Human Resources in fiscal year 2009. Currently, he leads our international
	business (Asia Pacific and Europe) and oversees Human Resources and Marketing Communications. Prior
	to joining us, Mr.&nbsp;Gustafson held various consulting and consulting management positions, including
	serving as Managing Director of Arthur D. Little (Southeast Asia and Greater China) from 2000 to
	2004, and as a consultant with Bain &#038; Company from 1986 to 1988. In addition, Mr.&nbsp;Gustafson has
	held senior management positions in the commercial building products sector, including serving as
	Vice President of Marketing for American Buildings Company from 2005 to 2006, and Director of
	Marketing with Varco-Pruden from 1988 to 1993. He has a Bachelor of Arts from the University of
	California Santa Barbara and an MBA from the University of Chicago.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<B>
<I>
	Brian Holte
</I>
</B>
	is our Vice President &#151; General Manager Western Division. Mr.&nbsp;Holte joined us in March
	2007. Before joining us, Mr.&nbsp;Holte spent 17&nbsp;years at Rockwell Automation, a global leader in power,
	control and information solutions for the manufacturing and infrastructure business sectors. During
	his time at Rockwell Automation, Mr.&nbsp;Holte gained extensive experience in sales, industry
	marketing, business development, sales leadership and regional management. Mr.&nbsp;Holte has a Bachelor
	of Science in Industrial Technology from the University of Wisconsin, Stout and an MBA from
	University of Southern California.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<B>
<I>
	Sean O&#146;Sullivan
</I>
</B>
	is our Vice President &#151; Investor and Media Relations. Mr.&nbsp;O&#146;Sullivan joined us in
	December&nbsp;2008. For the eight years prior to joining James Hardie, Mr.&nbsp;O&#146;Sullivan was Head of
	Investor Relations at St. George Bank, where he established and led the Investor Relations
	function. Mr.&nbsp;O&#146;Sullivan&#146;s background includes thirteen years as a fund manager for GIO Asset
	Management with responsibility for domestic and global investments. During this period, he spent a
	period of time on secondment with McKinsey and Co. After leaving the GIO, Mr.&nbsp;O&#146;Sullivan worked for
	Westpac in funds management sales. Mr.&nbsp;O&#146;Sullivan has a Bachelors of Arts majoring in Economics
	from Sydney University and an MBA from Macquarie Graduate School of Management.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<B>
<I>
	Nigel Rigby
</I>
</B>
	is our Vice President &#151; General Manager Eastern Division. Mr.&nbsp;Rigby joined us in 1998
	as a Planning Manager for our New Zealand business and has held a number of sales, marketing and
	product and business development roles with us. In November&nbsp;2004, Mr.&nbsp;Rigby became Vice President &#151;
	Emerging Markets. In 2006, he was named Vice President &#151; General Manager Northern Division. In
	November&nbsp;2008, he became Vice President &#151; General Manager of the newly-formed Eastern Division,
	which incorporates the former Northern and Southern Division markets and plants. Before joining us,
	Mr.&nbsp;Rigby held various management positions at Fletcher Challenge, a New Zealand based company
	involved in energy, pulp and paper, forestry and building materials.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	None of the persons above has any familial relationship with each other. In addition, none of the
	individuals listed above is party to any arrangement or understanding with a major shareholder,
	customer, supplier or other entity, pursuant to which any of the above was selected as a director
	or member of senior management.
</DIV>

	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="BORDER-TOP: 3PX DOUBLE #000000">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<!-- END TABLE BODY -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Our Plant City, Florida Hardie Pipe Plant was closed and the business ceased operations in May
	2008. As of the end of March&nbsp;31, 2009, of the 2,306 people employed, approximately 260 were members
	of labor unions (approximately 160 in Australia
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: TEXT-TOP">
	1
</SUP>
	and 100 in New Zealand). Our management
	believes that we have a satisfactory relationship with these unions and its members and there are
	currently no ongoing labor disputes. We currently have no employees who are members of a union in
	the United States or the Philippines. See Item&nbsp;3,
<BR>
	&#147;Key Information &#151; Risk Factors.&#148;
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT; MARGIN-TOP: 16PT; WIDTH: 18%; BORDER-TOP: 1PX SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
</DIV>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="96">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: TEXT-TOP">
	1
</SUP>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	Under Australian law, we cannot keep records of union
	members. The number quoted is the number of people who work in our factories
	that have union participation and therefore may be represented by a union.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	86
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>

	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_24"></A>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	Compensation
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<I>
	Remuneration
</I>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	The aggregate amount of compensation that we paid to, or accrued with respect to, all persons
	serving as members of our Supervisory Board, Managing Board or our executive officers (19 persons
	in aggregate) during fiscal year 2009 was approximately $13.6&nbsp;million. This figure consists of base
	salaries, bonuses paid, accrued compensation relating to awards of superannuation and retirement
	benefits, stock options, restricted stock and severance.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	The table below sets forth the compensation for those non-executive directors who served on the
	Board during the fiscal years ended March&nbsp;31, 2009 and 2008:

<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#A52931E20VF_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT; MARGIN-TOP: 16PT; WIDTH: 18%; BORDER-TOP: 1PX SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
</DIV>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="96">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	Amount includes base, Chairman, Deputy Chairman, Committee Chairman, Special Matter Committee
	attendance and Due Diligence Committee attendance fees.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(2)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	The actual amount spent by each Supervisory Board member was determined after deducting
	applicable Dutch taxes from this amount. The number of JHI NV shares acquired was determined
	by dividing the amount of participation in the Supervisory Board Share Plan 2006 (which we
	refer to as SBSP) by the market purchase price.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(3)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	Other Benefits includes the cost of non-executive directors&#146; fiscal compliance in The
	Netherlands. For Mr.&nbsp;DeFosset, fiscal year 2008 also includes for the period he was Chairman
	of the Joint and Supervisory Boards, office costs, the personal use of a company laptop and
	PDA phone.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(4)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	We pay for expenses related to Supervisory Board spousal travel to accompany them to up to
	one Board meeting per year. In fiscal year 2009, we paid $2,688, $2,878, $10,327, $14,407,
	$13,155, $10,253 and $4,238 for spousal travel for Messrs.&nbsp;Hammes, Harrison, McGauchie, van
	der Meer, Andrews, DeFosset and Loudon, respectively. In fiscal year 2008, we paid $15,984,
	$16,331 and $21,865 for spousal travel for Messrs.&nbsp;Hammes, McGauchie and Anderson,
	respectively.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(5)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	Mr.&nbsp;Harrison was appointed to the Company&#146;s Joint and Supervisory Boards effective May&nbsp;19,
	2008.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">

	&nbsp;
</DIV>
</DIV>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="96">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	Bonuses in respect of each fiscal year are paid in June of the following fiscal year. The
	amount in fiscal year 2009 includes all incentive amounts accrued for in respect of fiscal
	year 2009, pursuant to the terms of the applicable plans. The amount in fiscal year 2008
	includes all incentive amounts earned in respect of fiscal year 2008, pursuant to the terms of
	the applicable plans and the cash component of the Deferred Bonus Program.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	See &#147;Other Compensation&#148; for a summary of the terms of our incentive plans.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(2)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	Includes the aggregate amount of all noncash benefits received by the executive in the year
	indicated. Examples of noncash benefits that may be received by our executives include medical
	and life insurance benefits, car allowances, membership in executive wellness programs, long
	service leave, and tax services.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(3)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	Equity awards are valued using either the Black-Scholes pricing model or the Monte Carlo
	pricing method, depending on the plan the equity awards were issued under, and the fair value
	of equity awards granted are included in compensation during the period in which the equity
	awards vest.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(4)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	Other non-recurring benefits include cash paid in lieu of vacation accrued, as permitted
	under our U.S. vacation policy and California law.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(5)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	Mr.&nbsp;Cox joined the Company on January&nbsp;14, 2008 and became a member of the Managing Board
	effective May&nbsp;7, 2008. This table covers all of his remuneration for fiscal years 2009 and
	2008, including the remuneration before his appointment as a member of the Managing Board.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(6)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	Mr.&nbsp;Baker separated from the company effective March&nbsp;31, 2009. Mr.&nbsp;Baker received the U.S.
	equivalent of $73,899 on March&nbsp;31, 2009 as payment for his accrued vacation time and this is
	recorded as Other Non-recurring in this table.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(7)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	Mr.&nbsp;Rood separated from the Company on November&nbsp;3, 2008. Severance amount includes
	post-employment consulting fees paid in fiscal year 2009. As part of his separation benefits,
	Mr.&nbsp;Rood entered into a 2-year consulting agreement, under which he will be paid a consulting
	fee equivalent to his current annual salary, at the time of his separation, on a monthly basis
	for up to a period of 24&nbsp;months provided that the consulting agreement is not terminated
	earlier in accordance with its terms. Mr.&nbsp;Rood received cash of $33,330 as payment for his
	accrued vacation time and this is recorded as Other Non-recurring in this table.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	Employment Contracts
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Remuneration and other terms of employment for the Chief Executive Officer, Chief Financial
	Officer, General Counsel and certain other senior executives are formalized in employment
	contracts. The main elements of these contracts are set forth below.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Chief Executive Office
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Details of the terms of our Chief Executive Officer&#146;s employment contract are as follows:
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<TABLE STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT" CELLSPACING="0" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<!-- BEGIN TABLE HEAD -->

</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Initially a three year term, commencing
	February&nbsp;10, 2005. Term is automatically
	extended on 9th day of each February for an
	additional one year unless either party
	notifies the other, 90&nbsp;days in advance of the
	automatic renewal date, that it does not want
	the term to renew.
</TD>
</TR>

</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">

	annually by the Supervisory Board.
</TD>

<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<!-- BLANK SPACE -->

	Short-term incentive
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Annual short-term incentive target is 100% of
	annual base salary for the current year. The
	quantum of short-term incentive target is
	reviewed annually by the Supervisory
	Board.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<!-- BLANK SPACE -->
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	The Remuneration Committee recommends the
	Company&#146;s and Chief Executive Officer&#146;s
	performance objectives, and the performance
	against these objectives, to the Supervisory
	Board for approval. The Chief Executive
	Officer&#146;s short-term incentive is calculated
	under the Executive Incentive Plan (which
	includes the Individual Performance Plan).
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<!-- BLANK SPACE -->
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;

<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">

</TD>

	Long-term incentive
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Upon the approval of the shareholders, stock
	options or other equity incentive will be
	granted each year. The recommended number of
	options or other form of equity to be granted
	will be appropriate for this level of
	executive in the United States.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<!-- BLANK SPACE -->
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	&nbsp;

	&nbsp;

	&nbsp;
</TD>

<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	Defined Contribution Plan
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	The Chief Executive Officer may participate in
	the U.S. 401(k) defined contribution plan up
	to the annual IRS limit. The Company will
	match the Chief Executive Officer&#146;s
	contributions into the plan up to the annual
	IRS limit.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<!-- BLANK SPACE -->
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	Resignation
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	The Chief Executive Officer may cease
	employment with the Company by providing
	written notice.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<!-- BLANK SPACE -->
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	Termination by James Hardie
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	The Company may terminate the Chief Executive
	Officer&#146;s employment for cause or not for
	cause. If the Company terminates the
	employment, not for cause, or the Chief
	Executive Officer terminates his employment
	&#147;for good reason&#148; the Company will pay the
	following:
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<!-- BLANK SPACE -->
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	a. amount equivalent to 1.5 times
	the Chief Executive Officer&#146;s annual
	base salary at the time of termination; and
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	b. amount equivalent to 1.5 times the
	Chief Executive Officer&#146;s average short-term incentive
	actually paid in up to the previous three
	fiscal years as Chief Executive Officer; and
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	c. continuation of health and medical benefits
	at the Company&#146;s expense for the remaining
	term of the agreement and consulting agreement
	referenced below.
</TD>
</TR>

<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_28"></A>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<TABLE STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT" CELLSPACING="0" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<!-- BEGIN TABLE HEAD -->
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD WIDTH="25%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="70%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT" VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID #000000">
<B>
	Components
</B>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID #000000">
<B>
	Details
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
<!-- END TABLE HEAD -->
<!-- BEGIN TABLE BODY -->
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	Post-termination Consulting
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	The Company will request the Chief Executive
	Officer, and the Chief Executive Officer will
	agree, to consult to the Company upon
	termination for a minimum of two years, as
	long as the Chief Executive Officer maintains
	the Company&#146;s non-compete and confidentiality
	agreements and executes a release of claims
	following the effective date of termination.
	Under the consulting agreement, the Chief
	Executive Officer will receive the annual base
	salary and annual target incentive in exchange
	for this consulting and non-compete. Under the
	terms of equity incentive grants made to the
	Chief Executive Officer under the Managing
	Board Transitional Stock Option Plan and
	Long-Term Incentive Plan, the Chief Executive
	Officer&#146;s outstanding options will not expire
	during any post-termination consulting period.
	This arrangement is a standard arrangement for
	U.S. executives and the Supervisory Board
	considers that it is an appropriate restraint
	for Mr.&nbsp;Gries given his intimate involvement
	in developing the Company&#146;s fiber cement
	business in the U.S. over the past 18&nbsp;years.
</TD>
</TR>
<!-- END TABLE BODY -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>

</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>

</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Annual short-term incentive target is 33% of annual
	base salary as set out in his employment contract,
	based on personal goals under the Individual
	Performance Plan. The Chief Financial Officer does not
	participate in the Executive Incentive Plan for his
	short-term incentive other than the arrangement in
	fiscal years 2009 and 2010 where some of the Chief
	Financial Officer&#146;s long-term incentive target was
	transferred to short-term incentive target under the
	Executive Incentive Program.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<!-- BLANK SPACE -->
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	Long-term incentive
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Upon the approval of the shareholders, stock options
	or other long-term equity with performance hurdles
	will be granted each year. The recommended value of
	equity to be granted will be equivalent to at least
	$350,000. If the Chief Financial Officer ceases
	employment with the Company then a pro-rata amount of
	each tranche of the Chief Financial Officer&#146;s unvested
	options or other form of equity will expire on the date employment ceases,
	calculated based on the formula D=Cx(A/B), where A is
	the number of months from the date employment ceases
	to the first testing or vesting date, B is the number
	of months from the date of grant until the first
	testing or vesting date and C is the total number of
	options or other form of equity granted in the
	relevant tranche. The remaining unvested/unexercised
	options or other form of equity will continue as if
	the Chief Financial Officer remained employed by the
	Company until the first testing or vesting date, at
	which point any options or other form of equity that
	do not vest at that time will also lapse.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<!-- BLANK SPACE -->
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	Superannuation
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	The Company will contribute 9% of gross salary to the
	Chief Financial Officer&#146;s nominated superannuation
	fund.
</TD>
</TR>
<!-- END TABLE BODY -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	92
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>

</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>

</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">

	determined to be redundant or subject to a material
	diminution in status, duties or responsibility, the
	Company or the Chief Financial Officer may terminate
	the Chief Financial Officer&#146;s employment. The Company
	will pay the Chief Financial Officer a severance
	payment equal to the greater of 12&nbsp;months&#146; pay or the
	remaining proportion of the term of the contract.

</DIV>
</TD>

</TD>

	The General Counsel may cease employment with
	the Company by providing 30&nbsp;days&#146; written
	notice.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<!-- BLANK SPACE -->

<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	Termination by James Hardie
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	The Company may terminate the General
	Counsel&#146;s employment for cause or not for
	cause. If the Company terminates the
	employment, not for cause, or the General
	Counsel terminates his employment &#147;for good
	reason&#148;, the Company may request the General
	Counsel to consult to the Company for two
	years as set out below. No other termination payment is payable.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<!-- BLANK SPACE -->
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	Post-termination Consulting
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Depending on the reasons for termination, the
	Company may request the General Counsel, and
	the General Counsel will agree, to consult to
	the Company for two years upon termination, as
	long as he signs and complies with 1) a
	consulting agreement, which will require him
	to maintain non-compete and confidentiality
	obligations to the Company, and 2) a release
	of claims in a form acceptable to the Company.
	In exchange for the consulting agreement, the
	Company shall pay the General Counsel&#146;s annual
	base salary as of the termination date for
	each year of consulting.
</TD>
</TR>
<!-- END TABLE BODY -->
</TABLE>

<!-- BLANK SPACE -->
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	Long-term incentive
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Upon the approval of the
	Supervisory Board, restricted
	stock units have been granted
	under the long-term incentive
	plan in the form of Relative TSR
	restricted stock units and
	Executive Incentive Program
	restricted stock units.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<!-- BLANK SPACE -->
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	Defined Contribution Plan/Superannuation
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	U.S. senior executives may
	participate in the U.S. 401(k)
	defined contribution plan up to
	the annual IRS limit. The
	Company will match the senior
	executive&#146;s contributions into
	the plan up to the annual IRS
	limit.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<!-- BLANK SPACE -->
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	Resignation
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	The senior executive may cease
	employment with the Company by
	providing 30&nbsp;days&#146; written
	notice.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<!-- BLANK SPACE -->
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	Termination by James Hardie
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	The Company may terminate the
	senior executive&#146;s employment
	for cause or not for cause. Other than the post-termination
	consulting arrangement discussed below for a termination without
	cause or a resignation for good reason, no other termination payments
	are payable.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<!-- BLANK SPACE -->
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	Post-termination Consulting
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Depending on the senior
	executive&#146;s individual contract,
	and the reasons for termination,
	the Company may request the
	senior executive, and the senior
	executive will agree, to consult
	to the Company for two years
	upon termination, as long as
	they sign and comply with 1) a
	consulting agreement, which will
	require them to maintain
	non-compete and confidentiality
	obligations to the Company, and
	2) a release of claims in a form
	acceptable to the Company. In
	exchange for the consulting
	agreement, the Company shall pay
	the senior executive&#146;s annual
	base salary as of the
	termination date for each year
	of consulting.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<!-- BLANK SPACE -->
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	Other
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Health, Welfare and Vacation
	Benefits:
</B>
	Eligible to receive
	all health, welfare and vacation
	benefits offered to all U.S.
	employees and also eligible to
	participate in the Company&#146;s
	Executive Health and Wellness
	program.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<!-- BLANK SPACE -->
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Business Expenses:
</B>
	The senior
	executives are entitled to
	receive reimbursement for all
	reasonable and necessary travel
	and other business expenses
	incurred or paid in connection
	with the performance of services
	under their employment.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<!-- BLANK SPACE -->
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:-0PX">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Automobile:
</B>
	The Company will
	either lease an automobile for
	business and personal use by the
	senior executive, or, in the
	alternative, the executive will
	be entitled to an automobile
	lease allowance not to exceed
	$750 per month.
</TD>
</TR>
<!-- END TABLE BODY -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Brian Holte does not have such a written employment agreement, but receives short-term incentive,
	long-term incentive, defined contribution plan and other benefits as outlined above.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	95
<!-- /FOLIO -->

<TD ALIGN="RIGHT">
	&#151;
</TD>

<!-- END TABLE BODY -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>
</EFX_BENEFICIAL_OWNERS>

	19, 2001 under our 2001 Equity Incentive Plan in exchange for the termination of an award of
	shadow stock covering an equal number of shares of JHIL common stock. See &#147;Equity Plans &#151; 2001
	Equity Incentive Plan&#148; under Item&nbsp;6.

<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	Stock-Based Compensation
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	At March&nbsp;31, 2009, we had the following equity award plans: the Executive Share Purchase Plan
	(which we refer to as the Plan); the 2005 Managing Board Transitional Stock Option Plan; the
	JHI NV
	2001 Equity Incentive Plan; the
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	99
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage102"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#A52931E20VF_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Supervisory Board Share Plan 2006 and the Long-Term Incentive Plan
	2006 as amended in 2008 (which we refer to as LTIP).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Executive Share Purchase Plan
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Prior to July&nbsp;1998, JHIL issued stock under the Plan. Under the terms of the Plan, eligible
	executives purchased JHIL shares at their market price when issued. Executives funded purchases of
	JHIL shares with non-recourse, interest-free loans provided by JHIL and collateralized by the
	shares. In such cases, the amount of indebtedness is reduced by any amounts payable by JHIL in
	respect of such shares, including dividends and capital returns. These loans are generally
	repayable within two years after termination of an executive&#146;s employment. Variable plan accounting
	under the provisions of Accounting Principles Board (which we refer to as APB) Opinion No.&nbsp;25,
	&#147;Accounting for Stock Issued to Employees
<I>
	,
</I>
	&#148; has been applied to the Executive Share Purchase Plan
	shares granted prior to April&nbsp;1, 1995 and fair value accounting, pursuant to the requirements of
	SFAS No.&nbsp;123R, &#147;Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation,&#148; has been applied to shares granted after
	March&nbsp;31, 1995. The Company recorded no compensation expense during the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2009,
	2008 and 2007. No shares were issued under this plan during years ended March&nbsp;31, 2009, 2008 and
	2007.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Managing Board Transitional Stock Option Plan
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	The Managing Board Transitional Stock Option Plan provides an incentive to the members of the
	Managing Board. The maximum number of shares that may be issued and outstanding or subject to
	outstanding options under this plan without further shareholder approval is 1,320,000 shares. At
	March&nbsp;31, 2009 and 2008, there were 1,320,000 options outstanding under this plan.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	On November&nbsp;22, 2005, we granted options to purchase 1,320,000 shares of our common stock at an
	exercise price per share equal to A$8.53 to the Managing Board directors under the Managing Board
	Transitional Stock Option Plan. As set out in the plan rules, the exercise price and the number of
	shares available on exercise may be adjusted on the occurrence of certain events, including new
	issues, share splits, rights issues and capital reconstructions. Fifty percent of these options
	become exercisable on the first business day on or after November&nbsp;22, 2008 if the total shareholder
	returns (which we refer to as TSR) (essentially our dividend yield and common stock performance)
	from November&nbsp;22, 2005 to that date were at least equal to the median TSR for the companies
	comprising our peer group, as set out in the plan. In addition, for each 1% increment that our TSR
	is above the median TSR, an additional 2% of the options become exercisable. If any options remain
	unvested on the last business day of each six month period following November&nbsp;22, 2008 and November
	22, 2010, we will reapply the vesting criteria to those options on that business day.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<I>
	Effect of Change in Control.
</I>
	The 2005 Managing Board Transitional Stock Option Plan provides for
	the automatic vesting of certain benefits under the plan under certain circumstances in the event
	of a &#147;change in control.&#148; A &#147;change in control&#148; will be deemed to have occurred if&nbsp;either (1)&nbsp;a
	person obtains&nbsp;at least 30% of our voting shares pursuant to a takeover bid for all or a proportion
	of all of our voting shares which is or becomes unconditional, (2)&nbsp;a scheme of arrangement or other
	merger proposal becomes binding on the holders of all of our voting shares and by reason of such
	scheme or proposal a person obtains at least 30% of our voting shares, or (3)&nbsp;a person becomes the
	beneficial owner of at least 30% of our voting shares for any other reason.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	JHI NV 2001 Equity Incentive Plan
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Under our 2001 Equity Incentive Plan, our employees, including employees of our subsidiaries and
	officers who are employees, but not including any member of our Managing Board or Supervisory
	Board, are eligible to receive awards in the form of nonqualified stock options, performance
	awards, restricted stock grants, stock appreciation rights, dividend equivalent rights, phantom
	stock or other stock-based benefits such as restricted stock units. The 2001 Equity Incentive Plan
	is intended to promote our long-term financial interests by encouraging our management and other
	persons to acquire an ownership position in us, to align their interests with those of our
	shareholders and to
	encourage and reward their performance. The 2001 Equity Incentive Plan was approved by our
	shareholders and Joint Board subject to implementation of the consummation of our 2001
	Reorganization.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	An aggregate of 45,077,100 shares of common stock have been made available for issuance under the
	2001 Equity Incentive Plan, provided that such number (and any awards granted) is subject to
	adjustment in the event of a stock
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	100
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage103"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<A HREF="#A52931E20VF_HTM_TOCPAGE">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	split, stock dividend or other changes in our common stock or
	capital structure or our restructuring. Our ADSs evidenced by ADRs and our common stock in the form
	of CUFS will be equivalent to and interchangeable with our common stock for all purposes of the
	2001 Equity Incentive Plan, provided that ADSs will be proportionately adjusted to account for the
	ratio of CUFS in relation to ADSs.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	The following number of options to purchase shares of our common stock issued under this plan were
	as follows:
</DIV>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_37"></A>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">

	&nbsp;
</TD>

	&nbsp;

	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%">
	&nbsp;
